head.title: A Vinegar Substitute, With Half the Pucker

hedline.hl1: A Vinegar Substitute, With Half the Pucker

abstract.p: Wolffer Estate on Long Island produces verjuice, pale gold juice pressed from unripe white grapes, which can be used in sauces and as less acidic substitute for vinegar in salads; photo (S)

block.p: Verjuice is traditionally pressed from unripe white grapes, yielding a tart, pale gold juice to use in sauces and as a less acidic substitute for vinegar in salads. Roman Roth, the winemaker at Wölffer Estate in Sagaponack, N.Y., decided to make its ''verjus'' using unripe red grapes. The result, with the faintest blush, offers a sweet-sour balance of alluring delicacy. Try the verjuice for briefly poaching flounder fillets, then garnishing the fish with pink grapefruit segments. Cook down the pan juices, add a little butter and you have a lovely sauce. Wölffer verjus is $9.99 at the winery for a 750-milliliter bottle and $4.99 for half that size. The larger size is $14 at Dean & DeLuca in New York.
